instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PP_BUS_G3H: What is PP_BUS_G3H? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H When you see PP_BUS_G3H, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.CHGR_CSO_N: What is CHGR_CSO_N? CHGR_CSO_N is one of the current sense lines for the battery. Resistance between CHGR_CSO_N and CHGR_CSO_P should be the resistance should be the total series resistance of the current sense resistors in the circuit, usually about 2.2 ohms.
definitions.CHGR_CSO_P: What is CHGR_CSO_P? CHGR_CSO_P is one of the current sense lines for the battery. Resistance between CHGR_CSO_P and CHGR_CSO_N should be the resistance should be the total series resistance of the current sense resistors in the circuit, usually about 2.2 ohms.
definitions.CHGR_CSI_N: What is CHGR_CSI_N? CHGR_CSI_N is one of the current sense lines for the charger. Resistance between CHGR_CSI_N and CHGR_CSI_P should be the resistance should be the total series resistance of the current sense resistors in the circuit, usually about 20.02 ohms.
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.LVDS_IG_BKL_ON: What is LVDS_IG_BKL_ON? LVDS_IG_BKL_ON is equivalent to LCD_BKLT_EN. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LVDS_DDC_CLK: What is LVDS_DDC_CLK? LVDS_DDC_CLK Is the DDC clock line between the graphics processor and the screen. DDC is a protocol for identifying a screen so that you know what resolution/refresh rate it wants. This is necessary for screen detection, inductor on this data line must be good and DDC voltage must be going to the LCD screen for it to work. .
definitions.LVDS_DDC_DATA: What is LVDS_DDC_DATA? LVDS_DDC_DATA Is the DDC data line between the graphics processor and the screen. DDC is a protocol for identifying a screen so that you know what resolution/refresh rate it wants. This is necessary for screen detection, inductor on this data line must be good and DDC voltage must be going to the LCD screen for it to work. .
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is good at 3.43 at the one wire circuit
<SIGNAL>PP_BUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_S5_CHGR</SIGNAL>: 18.5V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 0 V

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>

RES PINS 27-28: 20.3 Ohm
RES PINS 17-18: 3.2 Ohm

2: 17.42V
3: 4.32 V
10: 3.47 V
11:3.47 V
14: 0 V
19: 5.09 V
20: 4.93 V

<RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR>: 7.6 K which seems low but ACIN (PIN 3) seems good

Since the current sensing seems good and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is receiving DC in fine I am assuming <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> is OK.
<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>: 0 volts so no signal to ONEWIRE

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> needs replacement?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
Any voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?
Why didn't post pin 1/<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> too?

Looks like bad <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
Before change it, post exact ohm values (measured onboard) for <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR>/81 and <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>/86.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
I will post those when I get home.

Do <SIGNAL>CHGR_SGATE</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CHGR_AGATE</SIGNAL> normally get shorted to ground so that the voltage dividers (<RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR>)
can fully open <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
Why did you replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> so fast?
You had just a bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>.

BTW, why do you post useless information???
"[FONT=Calibri][B]PIN 15: <SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>[/B][/FONT]
[FONT=Calibri][B]PIN 16: <SIGNAL>CHGR_BGATE</SIGNAL>[/B][/FONT]
[FONT=Calibri][B]PIN 17: <SIGNAL>CHGR_CSO_N</SIGNAL>[/B][/FONT]
[FONT=Calibri][B]PIN 18: <SIGNAL>CHGR_CSO_P</SIGNAL>"

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> could be bad, but never change something without reason.
You should change <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> first.[/B][/FONT]

"[FONT=Calibri][B]<TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR>: shorted to ground at SOURCE (PINS1-3)[/B][/FONT]"
I'm sure this is not true!!!
Remove power when check diode mode to ground; also allow 10-15s before measure.

Resolder F7040 and try to start in SMC bypass mode.

Also check for voltage pulse on all big coils.

BTW, you forgot to post L7260...

No start.

I will have to check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> but before I took F7040 out I think it was pulsing as well.

My ideas now:

1) <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>? could intermittent short on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> be a factor?
2) I was going to start checking MOSFETS that were just before the coils next?...like <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR>
3) Also check <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> with the <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> ?
4) Check <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> because of a slight flicker on MAGSAFE green light?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
I had left the board untouched for 12 hrs and I was actually getting a steady voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> for a while with a steady 0.35 amp draw on 18.5V power supply. But still no fan spin.

I had no idea what was going on.

As I handled the board, the pulsing started again on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> measured at F7040 pad 2.
Fan ticking like it wants to start.


WTF? Should I ultrasonic clean this board? [HR][/HR]

PIN 4

Just trying to understand the current sensing circuit functioning.

When I measured <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> prior to initially changing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> 5 days ago it was correct at 3 ohms.
I'm not sure how I messed that up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
You only needed two days to change mentioned components...

Missing image and backlight at same time?
Did you test external video?
Can you confirm USB activity at least?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
I cannot see an image on the screen (used a flashlight behind apple logo)
No backlight

I watched Louis' videos on this and started checking the following:


<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V with display connected
Diode mode reading on <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>: 0.60V
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN</SIGNAL>: 12 V
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>: 0 V
F9700 is good

<TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>
4: 12.4 V
1,2,5,6: 0 V
3: 12 V

Since <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> is a P type MOSFET that will only open when the voltage on the gate is much lower than the voltage on the source it seems like this is major issue.

<CAPACITOR>C9782</CAPACITOR> diode mode is 0.4 V
<RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR>: 300KO
<RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR>: 146kO


I think <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> is not opening. No path to ground.
<TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> never opens.

I think this LCD is never recognized to begin with.

Resistors on <SIGNAL>LVDS_DDC_DATA</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_DDC_CLK</SIGNAL> are good (exactly on spec).
<RESISTOR>R9008</RESISTOR> - 3.2kohms
<RESISTOR>R9009</RESISTOR> - 3.15kohms

J9000 connector looks good.
No corrosion.
NO Liquid damage evidence.
All pins look good.
LVDS PINS:
pin 2,3: 0 V
pin 6 - 0.560 diode mode
pin 7 - 0.643 diode mode

If <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>: 0V

<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>: 3.45 V



I followed:

[URL="https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/1359-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-no-backlight-missing-<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>/page2"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/for..._bklt_en/page2[/URL]


I will check with another LCD assembly.

Please remember that I am totally new to this.


<RESISTOR>R1981</RESISTOR>: 100K (<SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> = <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>)

<SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> is coming from <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> so I think I may be screwed.

If still the same, try known good working BIOS.
